Class ExtUnsupportedOperationException

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--java.lang.Throwable
        |
        +--java.lang.Exception
              |
              +--java.lang.RuntimeException
                    |
                    +--java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
                          |
                          +--de.susebox.java.lang.ExtUnsupportedOperationException
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, ThrowableList
public class ExtUnsupportedOperationException
extends java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
implements ThrowableList

Implementation of the ThrowableList interface for the well-known JDK UnsupportedOperationException.

Author:
Heiko Blau
See Also:
Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

ExtUnsupportedOperationException

public ExtUnsupportedOperationException(java.lang.String msg)
This constructor takes a simple message string like ordinary Java Throwable classes. This is the most convenient form to construct an ThrowableList throwable.

Parameters:
msg - message for this Throwable instance

ExtUnsupportedOperationException

public ExtUnsupportedOperationException(java.lang.Throwable ex)
This constructor should be used for wrapping another exception. While reading data an IOException may occur, but a certain interface requires a SQLException. Simply use: 
 try {
   ...
 } catch (NullPointerException ex) {
   throw new ExtUnsupportedOperationException(ex);
 }

Parameters:
ex - the exception to wrap

ExtUnsupportedOperationException

public ExtUnsupportedOperationException(java.lang.Throwable ex,
                                        java.lang.String msg)
If one likes to add ones own information to an exception, this constructor is the easiest way to do so. By using such an approach a exception trace with useful additional informations (which file could be found, what username is unknown) can be realized: 
 try {
   ...
 } catch (SQLException ex) {
   throw new IOException(ex, "while connecting to " + url);
 }

Parameters:
ex - the inner throwable
msg - throwable message

ExtUnsupportedOperationException

public ExtUnsupportedOperationException(java.lang.String fmt,
                                        java.lang.Object[] args)
This constructor takes a format string and its arguments. The format string must have a form that can be used by MessageFormat methods. That means: 
    java.text.Message.format(fmt, args)
is similar to 
    new MyException(fmt, args).getMessage();

Parameters:
fmt - throwable message
args - arguments for the given format string

ExtUnsupportedOperationException

public ExtUnsupportedOperationException(java.lang.Throwable ex,
                                        java.lang.String fmt,
                                        java.lang.Object[] args)
This is the most complex way to construct an ExceptionList- Throwable.
An inner throwable is accompanied by a format string and its arguments. Use this constructor in language-sensitive contexts or for formalized messages. The meaning of the parameters is explained in the other constructors.

Parameters:
ex - the inner throwable
fmt - throwable message
args - arguments for the given format string
Method Detail

getCause

public java.lang.Throwable getCause()
Retrieving the cause of a Throwable. This is the method introduced with JDK 1.4. It replaces the older nextThrowable().

Specified by:
getCause in interface ThrowableList
Overrides:
getCause in class java.lang.Throwable
Returns:
the cause of this Throwable
See Also:
Throwable.getCause()

nextThrowable

public java.lang.Throwable nextThrowable()
Deprecated. use the JDK 1.4 call getCause() instead

Method to traverse the list of Throwable. See ThrowableList.nextThrowable() for details.

Specified by:
nextThrowable in interface ThrowableList
Returns:
the "earlier" throwable

isWrapper

public boolean isWrapper()
Check if this is only a throwable that wraps the real one. See ThrowableList.isWrapper() for details.

Specified by:
isWrapper in interface ThrowableList
Returns:
true if this is a wrapper exception, false otherwise

getFormat

public java.lang.String getFormat()
Getting the format string of a exception message. This can also be the message itself if there are no arguments.

Specified by:
getFormat in interface ThrowableList
Returns:
the format string being used by MessageFormat
See Also:
getArguments()

getArguments

public java.lang.Object[] getArguments()
Retrieving the arguments for message formats. These arguments are used by the MessageFormat.format(java.lang.Object[], java.lang.StringBuffer, java.text.FieldPosition) call.

Specified by:
getArguments in interface ThrowableList
Returns:
the arguments for a message format
See Also:
getFormat()

getMessage

public java.lang.String getMessage()
Implementation of the standard Throwable.getMessage() method. It delegates the call to the central ThrowableMessageFormatter.getMessage(de.susebox.java.lang.ThrowableList) method.

Overrides:
getMessage in class java.lang.Throwable
Returns:
the formatted throwable message
See Also:
ThrowableMessageFormatter
